comment:
3.25/5

Like a New York bakery, minty rye all around. Clean, and a little potent.
Kick you with a grassy nose and spicy rye flavors. Mint and anise and oak finish. A little hot, but great for mixing. a MGPI sourced blend by HW...who does it so well.

Every time I have a pour I think, “why do I like this so much?” Rye is certainly a lesser traveled whisky road for me, so is it the unfamiliar notes that resonate? Maybe it’s the garden box of herbs & botanicals on the nose? Perhaps the spicy and unusual (for me at least) black licorice/citrus zest/mint/molasses combo on the palate? Whatever it is, the Double Rye is smooth and enjoyable.

Rating: the Distiller score seems about right although I’d probably go 2-3 pts less. No reason why this rye shouldn’t have a spot in any cabinet at a very reasonable $34 (can even be found south of $30 for the bargain hunter). Cheers & enjoy
Spicy and smooth, perfect for the eve of fall
My first impression is it is no good. I will continue to work on it though.
Don’t have much experience with rye, but this is pretty tasty. Little sweet up front and spicy. Very smooth. Dig it.
Barrel Select Double Rye: Minty spices on the nose. Maybe a touch of lemon zest? Taste is all grassy rye with lingering oak and heat. Def keeping Double Rye around. 90/100
Starts out a bit hot. Texture is heavy on the tongue. I really enjoyed it, but the lingering aftertaste didn’t sit well. The longer on the tongue the less I like it
lots of rye and a bit spicy when first opened.  gets better after being opened awhile
Enjoyable if a tad on the pricey side.  Interesting anise note.

3.3/5.0 - 2nd generation (house distillate plus MGP.  No 16-yr).

Mint, lemon zest and a hint of soap on the nose.  Gentle with the barest hint of alcohol.

The taste is very light and vegetal.  Herbs.  Characteristic rye cinnamon but the barley is easily identified.  Relatively thin - watery mouthfeel.

Finish is gentle but long, mostly a pleasant cinnamon across the tongue.

Tastes young but not harsh.  Well made and fair at msrp ($30); a value for less (seen as low as $26).  A unique flavor that stands out from the pack.
Delicious... I don’t know how to explain the flavors. All I know is... bang for buck is at the top of the chart for me
Nose has a strong clove with some cinnamon. Smooth start with a bite at the end. Definitely can taste the anise and mint at the end. Even better with pumpkin pie.
If you like-a-da spice..... this for you.
tip of toung sweet. spice mid. herbal after taste.
I had the 2017 Binny’s, with 10 months finish in Pinot noir

This is a smooth, easy-drinking whiskey. It is spicy, but not as spicy as the label “double rye” would have you believe. There is nothing particular memorable about the drink. It neither offends nor stands out in any particular way. It is balanced, safe, and uninspiring.
A little harsher than something like a wood ford reserve double oak but with the right hint of sweetness and oak.

High West should be my favourite American whiskeys distiller, and this one is my favourite from High West. 

They just don't have the natures I personally dislike from most American whiskeys - super sweet, super corny, overall incomplex and spiciness that is quite jarring.
not much barrel, mint and herbal somewhat thin mouthfeel
I keep getting drawn to this neat, as well as in an old fashioned.  Just a solid rye all around.

Sweet and spicy with strong, dry, woody finish with rye grain and caraway.  Very robust with a syrupy mouthfeel.  Some sweetness on the palate.  Some vanilla.  Not my favorite rye, but it's thoroughly competent.
really nice, I think the best High West
Magnum’s barrel selection finished in Robert Mondavi Zinfandel barrels. 100 proof. Woody and sweet. Love the nuance the zin casks add. 4.2.
Really full flavor, kick equal throughout but fruity
Smooth. Not too hot.  Have with out ice

Tasting neat.

Nose:  Licorice, mint, a little alcohol.

Taste: Cane sugar, light body, light licorice, menthol, clove, juniper, green and pink peppercorn and general rye herbs..with some sweet oak, leather, touch of smoke, and tartness in the finish. 

This will always be in my cabinet.  It's priced like a daily and tastes like your birthday.  If you like Bulleit Rye, but want a little more of the age and oak, without losing the bright spice, then this is your jam.

For the price it's amazing. Surprising mellow on the nose and first mouth cover with hints of wood and vanilla, mouth feel of molasses after swallowing. A tingling sensation of spice/cinnamon comes in late and lingers gently on the tongue and mouth to a soothing finish.  Can see why it would be a great add into a mixed drink.

Spice, vermouth, black licorice taste

Smoooooooth
Excellent flavor. Not much burn. Rich flavors.
Spicy and strong but still smooth

3cL Sample from Fine Drams.

Nose: sweet rye, leather, vanilla, anise
Palate: Medium spice, vanilla, caramel, coriander. Rich, complex, sweet, delicious neat. No burn. Wet grass on the second sip, but it doesn't last. Hides the young age well.
Finish: Longer with no burn. Declicious.

I'd probably buy more of this just because it is so affordable. Wish it was higher proof, but this is a great enough neat sipper and should be big enough for most cocktails.  Need a bit more in an OF, though.
Great mid price rye.  My goto for Old Fashion
Didn't enjoy the first whiff... Too much mint comes off almost as a cleanser. Burn builds and lingers. Cinnamon and leather does make an appearance. I like it but don't live it

smell: light. cherry-maraschino cherry?. taste: cherry. lemon. vanilla? 

would be good cold, but maybe not watered down with ice. tastes are too subtle for that

This is the second rye I've ever had, so I don't have much to compare this to, but I like it! On the nose I get the smell of rye bread, along with some star anise, vanilla, and wood. Tastewise, I get more rye, cereal, mint, pine, anise, and some vanilla sweetness. Finish is pretty cool with the mint notes. Nice change of pace when you're not in the mood for a sweet whiskey like bourbon or a speyside scotch, but I'm not sure how good a value this is compared to other ryes on the market. 

Update: My second glass of this a few days after my first had more muted flavors than it did the first time. Depending on how the flavor changes as I go through the bottle the score may go down a bit.
Rating a Barrel Select Limited Release bottle - amazing smoothness
Smells full of spice notes with hints of sweet notes, tastes full of flavor, great spice notes with full body and sweet notes. An amazing deal!
Spicy right off the bat. Strong dill pickle notes, but mild alcohol burn despite the higher ABV.
Spice, vanilla. Good, but may not buy again.

I get cloves and fruit and a hint of pepper on the nose. Smooth and sweet compared to most ryes. The cloves continue (a little too prominently) when you taste it and finishes with prunes and then apricots. Not something you would drink all night, but distinctive so a good sampler for comparison.
Of the four rye's that I've drank, this is my favorite. Lots of complex flavors and smooth. A little pricey, but a damn fine whiskey.
Spice, pine, frosting, lemon peel, rose water and some toastiness. Peach, citrus and herbs with a light bitterness. Nicely integrated complexity.

Incredible in an old fashioned.  Simply the best I’ve had.  The spiciness works so well.  I would recommend using angostura and Demerara + an orange peel. Don’t cut with any water.  Avoid processed sugar, muddled cherries, sweeter bitters, or anything else that adds too much sweetness, and instead let the spiciness drive.  It’s really something special.  Unfortunately, I now have trouble enjoying old fashioneds made with other whiskies.
Loving the spiciness with this. Perfect!
smooth & soft bite, tones of vanilla in the nose & on the pallet. Clean, no excessive overdone characteristics.

Nose: Licorice, aniseed, dill
Taste: Barrel bitter, dill, wet grass / lemongrass, licorice, rye bread maltiness,aniseed, green apple, a bit of vanilla, lavender / dark intense rose / floral, cinnamon with clove and brown sugar,

Dill is by far the dominant note, always there. There is some complexity to it, but it gets buried very quickly by the dill. Had to add a few drops of water to open it up. Very good for the rye lover probably. This is my first rye so it is a little weird.
Lavender, mint, lemon, allspice. Kind of a soapy boozy taste. It’s got the bones but the nose isn’t there.
noticeable rye flavor! delicious and spicy

I enjoyed this rye. I never tried the batches that included the 16 yr rye from Barton so can’t compare, but everything I have read says the older recipe was a lot better.  That being said, this is a solid offering at a reasonable price (unlike their other whiskeys). If you are deciding between this and Rendezvous Rye (ignoring the $40 price difference) get this one. It has 2-7 year ryes. Rendezvous has 4-7 year ryes. Same mashbills.

Nose: mint, leather, alcohol heat
Palate: leather, sweet oatmeal, 
Finish: complex, pepper, cinnamon, and a very nice long lingering spicy rye tail
Notes of cinnamon and caramel apple, smooth, screams Rye yet very little burn.
The mint and odd mix of licorice along with a sort of heavy aftertaste took some of the fun out for me. Good burn, but an odd flavor.
Used to be my go to when it was all MGP. I’m afraid it’s no longer good with HW in the mix.

Last year High West announced a pretty major shift in the make up of this Rye. Historically, this has been a blend of a 2 yr old MGP distilled rye (95% rye and 5% Malted barley) and a 16 yr old rye (53% rye, 37% corn and 10% Malted barley) distilled @ Barton in KY. I have always viewed it as a great value rye worth sipping neat or making a fabulous Manhattan. 
So what was the change? High West replaced the 16 yr old Rye with their own Distillate which is aged for between 4-7 yrs. It has a very unique Mashbill (80% rye and 20% Malted Rye). The 2 yr old rye is retained and makes the base of the new blend (greater than 50%). What's more is that High West makes the bold statement that no change in quality or flavor profile will be noticed! I thought no way that was possible. Then I tasted this year's MidWinter which also included the new Distillate for the first time and was really impressed. Then we saw Whiskey Advocate include it in their annual Top 20 list. Finally, old faithful Costco stocked it and I picked up this bottle for just $29. 
Now in order to ensure you have the new recipe, check the batch # and ensure is starts with a 18. My batch # is 18018 for reference. 
Now that you are well versed with the history, let's move to the tasting!
On the pallette you get those classic and nice MGP rye notes of honey and clove with caramel apples to augment it. Mid pallette show some more spice with a nice botanical/herbal undertone. Finish is medium in length with caramel, clove and mint. All in all it's a really nice pour. Slightly sweeter than the previous iteration but also more complex. 
It's quite an achievement by High West that they can create such complexity whilst losing a 16 yr old component. 
I would say this is the best sub $30 Rye I have had to date. Beats out Rittenhouse BiB and Baby Saz hands down. 
Lovely effort and really worthy of it's inclusion on the WA Top 20 list of 2018. If you like Rye, find a batch starting with 18. You won't be dissapionted!

Nose - Charred Oak, mint, cinnamon 

Taste - Rye spice, vanilla, cinnamon 

Finish - Warming and sweet. Tastes young but has just enough complexity to justify drinking neat
Very spicy, but clean and quick finish. Tasty but not too strong.
excellent rye for the price, very smooth; great for cocktails and a good sipper
The double rye is very rich and full. The spice is well balanced with flavors of mint, and finishes with hints of cinnamon.
Not sure how to describe. Rich, spicy, gravely. One of my favorites. Proud American Rye!  Tastes like Bazooka Joe and gun powder.
Spicy, strong up front flavor but a surprisingly short linger of alcohol.  Really good
Spicy warmth with a smooth finish with a hint of floral on the end

Light and fruity with hints of star anise, lemon zest, pickle brine, cracked peppercorns, eucalyptus, and rye bread. Honey sweetness and a bit of cinnamon come in and keep it from tasting overly herbal. Great for drinking on a warm day. Love at first taste.
mint, chocolate, leather and oak aroma. sharp, spicy leather flavor .  perfumy
This is certainly not your standard Rye. Sweeter and with a definite note of dill and anise.

Nose: rye jumps out of the glass, pickle, caramel, leather, pine
Taste: spicy, salty, rye bread, some sweetness that I can’t pinpoint 
Finish: almost minty, some licorice 
After reading reviews: confirmation of the pine, mint, and leather.  The unidentifiable sweetness may be the confectioners sugar noted in whizzky - I didn’t find honey or vanilla.  I don’t like gin or really know what juniper is like, so I wouldn’t have gotten that.  surprised I didn’t see pickle or salt noted.  Overall, the pine and mint are a little weird for me.

The first rye I have even been able to stand. It’s not bad but I would drink it as a daily. I’m goin to try to make some mixers out of it and see if it shines through. But so far it is my favorite rye I have had. Not to harsh and a very nice nose.

I am not a big rye fan, but this is surprisingly good.  It still has the, "giant hole" in it's flavor profile that seems to plague most every rye I have tasted, but HW still comes through with some good flavors.  I am a big cinnamon fan and this rye is short on cinnamon and cloves.  It has back of the mouth heat which is much preferable to the front heat that lesser drinks seem to provide.  My rye of choice is the Sazerac 6yr(now NAS).  It is full of cinnamon, has more flavor than HW, and is only $29.  It is not as readily available, but it is a better value.  I would like to try the HW Rendezvous Rye, but it is even pricier.  I understand that rye leaves space in it's profile for mixologist to operate and fill in the blanks, but I much prefer a dram that is more ready to drink.
Forget listerine, and go for some of this for a minty note
Classic rye with dill and anise notes. Has some complex underlaying notes such as hay and barn grain. Drying finish with classic rye cinnamon spice

Nose - Leather, Butterscotch, Mint
Palate - Sweet Rye and Dill
Finish - Surprisingly smooth, cool Spearmint then more Dill

Nose: spearmint, juniper, earl grey tea

Palate: leather

Finish: rye, liquorish

Nose: spearmint, juniper, tea, dill pickle, pipe tobacco 

Taste: candy cane, tiny bit of licorice, tiny bit of pickle, pipe tobacco, anise
So tasty - vanilla, brown sugar, cinnamon heat, spearmint, smooth.
great for the price point, best spice, incredibly smooth with spice
Never heard of this before trying it. Really nice surprise! Very smooth.

Batch 18I18
Nose is softly fragrant of rye spice and freshly baked sugar cookies, with a floral element of honeysuckle. Rye spice and anise dominate the palate, which to me create an unpleasant herbal medicine taste. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, with just a little alcohol burn. Finish is long and warm, but dominated by the herbal/anise quality. I don't get much sweetness on this except on the nose. The anise taste puts me off sipping this neat, but it works well as a mixer.

Nose: Rye, Floral, Honey, Oak

Taste: Carmel, Honey, Rye Spice, Leathery
interesting spice but a tad astringent

Spacy 
Sweet
Easy to drink 
Rocks
heavy spice on front end. lingering flavors of clove, cinnamon, and wood with a slight fruity undertone. very oily mouthfeel which may contribute to the length of the flavor.
One of my favorite ryes, especially given the price. Always try to keep this one in stock for my bar.
So smooth and easy drinking. Flavor is not overly deep and the finish is short but drinks so nice. Good daily drinker.
I am loving this stuff!  Mint...Tea...Sweet...and moderate finish.  Great Rye for $31 in Tulsa!
Great spice. Like this better than the normal high west rye.

Not much for the snooty notes on floral etc. I’ve been drinking this cheap of the HWD line for years and a cheap taste it is NOT. I guess I’m more of a feel taster than actual chemical notes and composition. This Rye pairs well with any John Ford or Clint Eastwood western. It absolutely goes awesome with string cheese and veggies and hummus. I especially love this drink when binging Mad Men. No I was not drinking too much of this when I wrote my review...”mother”....
I quess I'm not a big fan of rye's, not on my favorites list...
best over rocks slightly diluted. Grassy and a bit harsh strait but with an ice cube mellows out nicely. Definitely bold and spicy. Finishes quick with mild sweet taste.
Clove, cinnamon and mint on the nose, smooth, sweet rye with cinnamon on the palate, long spicy finish
The typical spice is present for the style yet it is the fruity & minty notes that win me over. This could be my go-to sipping Rye and it’s a fun hunt finding it at the right price point.
Initial light sweetness followed by a strong cinnamon spice. A nice straight drinking whiskey!
Not too complex, some spicy notes with a bit of oak

Tasted again neat with nothing accompanying:
Color- warm, deep, amber
Nose- fresh and herbal, mint stands
Palate- A slick, creamy sweetness hits the tongue with caramel, a hint of spice and mint the major player again. The finish trails off moderately with a warming baking spice & light oak

Nose: Sweet, white wine
Taste: mild, orange, honey, butterscotch, vanilla, nut
Finish: mild tannin, oak, nutty
Caramel nose. Lingering pepper and light sweetness.
Decent whiskey, flavor is a bit unique compared to other ryes I've tasted.  At $36 I probably won't buy this.

Nose is very astringent.
Flavors of pepper, cinnamon, and oak.
Spicy.

I have to admit this is my first rye so I don’t have anything to compare it to but boy has this one opened my eyes. I’m not a huge fan of rye bread so I kind of always stayed clear of the rye bourbons but I saw an old style bottle of this on clearance and couldn’t resist the urge. There is something about this that just feels right. The rye was obviously  there in the nose but I also got whiffs of what I can only describe as sawdust. The palate was smooth as butter and it wasn’t exactly what I was expecting. The finish to me is where this one shines, that’s where I found the pronounced rye I was looking for, although not at all overpowering.
So glad I took the chance on this one, has really opened up my world to a whole other side of whiskey that I never thought I would enjoy.
As the bottle describes.  Would buy again.
Decent. A little harsh straight up but was good in ginger ale.
Superb rye at this price point.
Standard rye on the nose. Sweet candy. On the palate. Not much spice. Short to moderate  finish. Desert rye. Good stuff.
Minty, nice change up scotch or bourbon
No alcohol burn, a little sweet, lots of spice in ther clove type family
Orange peel, caramel, cayenne pepper.  I liked it a lot but didn’t feel like it lived up to the ratings and hype.

My new budget rye.

Love this stuff. Nose is stringent black tea, eucalyptus and rye spice. Taste is black tea, rye spice and caramel. Nice long finish. Would be a good rye to introduce someone to rye with.

A staple in my cabinet! There are rye's that drink better straight, but most of them are at least double the price. It's the best mixing rye I've had. It makes a great old fashioned, a killer whiskey sour, and I'd take it over most bourbons in a mint julep. If you're thinking about a bottle of this pull the trigger!
VEry spicy but also very rich and sweet.

Super impressed with this for the price. It’s rather subtle and almost muted on the nose, leaving something to be desired. But first taste is fantastic. Been sipping for the last 2 hours and the sips become bigger and better with each passing minute. Will definitely buy again.

Nose: cherry and cinnamon spice 

Palate: rye spice layered with toasted marshmallows and bread. 

Finish: lingering dry spice
Could drink this on the reg. Seems on the sweeter side for a rye but no complaints

If you can find the older bottling this is amazing stuff. Unfortunately they changed the recipe. But if you’re lucky enough to find one previous to them running out of the 16 yr old mix you’re in for a treat. I happen to have honey hole that has a shelf full of the “old” stuff but the price has been jacked up to the current Double Rye price so a $15 bump for me but I’ll still pay the extra for this. I just tasted ECBP, ECSB, pikesville rye, and angels envy rye along side this stuff and it’s the clear winner!! I’m going to make this bottle last as long as I can.
Great rye flavor with an herbal accent that enhances the rye nicely

Batch reviewed is 19H06. Color is a basic amber. Nose has a faint oiliness, with notes of mild ethanol, faint evergreen, and subtle rye spice. First sip is pleasantly spicy, with a blend of classic rye spice, baking spice, and a very mild baseline sweetness. Mouthfeel is full, very slightly oily. Finish is a little short, with a continuation of the backing spices. Additional sips reveal subtle notes of the evergreen/juniper.
Smooth and sweet.... easy drink. Not super remarkable, but will flow down nonetheless.
Tastes young and spicy. Pleasant, but would make better cocktails than neat pours.

A lot of fun and refreshing. Real smooth and easy to drink

Nose: first sniff spice cabinet. Then you pick up some mint. Bright berry. Light burn
Pallet: front all spice, herby, rye. Hint of brown sugar and mid to finish floral vanilla. 
Finish: medium linger. Vanilla and a touch of oak.
Pretty good rye. It’s nice to reach for this when wanting some different than bourbon or scotch.
A splendid rye blend with almost no alchohol burn. Excellent for someone toeing the rye waters. Spicey, but not overpowering as some ryes can be.
Floral nose, black pepper spice. Oily linger.
Spicy nose that carries throughout. Gentle smoke that lingers on the palate. Full bodied with a medium oily mouthfeel.
Lots of baking spices on the nose. The taste is lots of cinnamon with a hint of licorice. One of my favorite ryes.
A little sweet and not overly rye spicy. Was hoping for more rye flavor.
Love the spice, and the herbal notes!

Nose: floral and hint of spice

Palate: rich oily smoky rye with clove and anise 

Finish: long, full, rich, and smooth
Spice and funk. Quite a bit of heat too.
Bottle started out strong with some great spicy fruit notes. Towards the end some oily acetone flavors crept in
Smooth and easy to drink .... and perfect in an old fashioned.

Extremely spice forward. DILL PICKLE. Medicinal. Anise, dill, and juniper nose. Drinks smoother than 46%. Full body. Cherry on the finish. One of the more interesting, non finished whiskeys I’ve had. Won’t be a go-to rye for me. Perhaps this is the extreme end of where Rye whiskey should go?
Good cinnamon flavor. Good for old fashion
Big, spicy and smooth. Very good.
Smooth rye but still sweet like bourbon
Middle of the road. Has a little bite. Notes of caramel and tannins. Overall pretty average.

I’ve had a few high West products and thought I’d try out this particular rye offering. Price list is for 375ml.

The nose has, wait for it... Rye! Also, I pick up cola, anise, corn some baking spices, vanilla and some sweetness.

The palate is light and slightly creamy in texture. There is a good amount of rye, vanilla, slightly dusty barn, and a little sweetness.

The finish is long with lingering rye spice and a slow burn on the sides of tongue and throat. Very nice.

At this point, I wouldn’t consider myself a “rye guy”, but this is nice and enjoyable. 
It doesn’t actually have any corn in it after looking up the mashbills used in this blend, so it’s interesting that corn was a somewhat prominent note that I was picking up.
Tastes like grass. Needs significantly more time aging.
Alcohol bite on the nose. Mint on the front and a spice (maybe cloves) on the back. Lingers a while. Very complex

Tasted next to midwinter nights dram act 7 Scene 2

Nose: sprightly, sweet mint, sweet cinnamon, and rich sweet floral notes. Reminds me of a spring flower garden in full bloom.

Palate: follows the nose exactly, but finishes with a nicely dry oak
One of my favorite daily drinkers. I enjoy this year round, but especially during the holidays due to the nice spice notes.

N: sour apple, pumpernickel, pepper
P: straight up rye, dried fruit, vanilla
F: medium

A must try for anyone wanting to get into American Ryes. Plesant floral and spicy notes that taste much younger than most of the other High West offerings. Beware of the strong dill taste that lasts throughout if that is something you do not like.
Very floral notes, taste a kin to a gin. Very interesting.
Sweet caramel and lots of baking spice, with a nice bite.
This is a good pour! Floral and citrus on top of the dark spicy flavors of good ryes.
Excellent whiskey, strong presence of oak
Side by side next to Four Roses Small Batch, this has more flavor and less burn with a longer finish.
Full body. Smoky, cinnamon and vanilla

Aroma: old leather, taven and deep wood. Musty

Flavor: Spicey, caramel, woody. Has a bite
Caramel, barrel, cinnamon, dried apricot, heavy winter spice

A solid entry level young rye. Spicy at first with a slow warm finish. spices, clove. Clean smooth simple and young nose, a little too light on complexity to be high quality but a solid and enjoyable everyday or cheaper whisky. $35 would buy again and keep around. Try nicer versions of this mash bill
Sugar and spice.  It's not too sweet like bourbon.  It doesn't taste like any other rye out there.

2018 batch. Dill and mint herbal notes on the nose. Sweet and spicy. Hoping to find some 2017 or older bottles with the original blend formula that includes some of the 16 year old Barton's rye. Plan to do a side by side comparison. For 2018 and newer bottles, HW replaced the Barton's with their own distillate.
Spicy then sweet.  Awesome.  W Steven NYE 2019-20.
Cinnamon, anise, honey, a little water.
Underrated rye. Smooth. Oaky. Minty finish. Complex. Under $50 I might purchase again.

Tasted neat in a glencairn.  About 5 minutes was allowed to pass after the pour for the liquor to rest. The pour is brassy gold with thin sheeting and very little in the way of legs.

The nose is cherry coughdrops, menthol, ethanol, and an almond note reminiscent of amaretto.  There's a sweetness element and an alcohol element and they seem a bit disjointed and perhaps a little thin.

The taste is initially sweet with cherry, vanilla, dill, cloves and mint. The initial sweetness fades quickly to a somewhat dry mid-note that carries a tinge of bitterness and this carries into the beginning of a peppery finish.  This is a spicy rye with a bright, young personality.  

This is an acceptable rye when served neat.  Its definitely not in the class of Pikesville, or even Templeton Good Stuff (the latter being a guilty pleasure of mine when straight, but a bit weak in the knees to go head-to-head in a cocktail)

I find it to be a good candidate for a big rock and casual sipping.  It works very well in a Manhattan, also.  This rye has an affinity for vermouth, in particular in a perfect Manhattan with Noilly Prat rouge and extra dry 50-50. 

This is a good bottle and I'm glad I sampled it.  I got it on sale for $27.99.  It's worth that, but it has some stiff competition.   I probably would take an Old Overholt BiB or a Rittenhouse over this.  I do like this better than OF rye.  

I guess there's enough rye in the $20 to $30 range that this isn't going to be a repeat purchase for me.  It's right near the highest point on the bell curve along with all the other the average players, and that's not quite good enough to get excited about.
Solid. It’s a great everyday rye. I’m a fan.
Solid. Basically the same whiskey as bulleit just a little more expensive
Belated review. Dry, spicy, oaky, and young, but not too hot. Some green apple notes as well. Really digging the vibrant spicy rye character.

I can't quite ignore the fact that MGP has a finger in this pie. High West's Double Rye is totally pleasant and tastes good neat. Like Bulleit, this is balanced so as to please crowds and not diverge too wildly from what we're coming to expect from "straight rye," and so this tastes good without wowing.
Had a taste of Jakes at Blue Oit and thoroughly enjoyed the bold rye. Double rye as in two different rye grains in the mash. Would try again but might not go out of my way to find
Truly fantastic. Sips wonderfully despite peppery spice that makes the ears tingle. Wonderfully complex.

Nose is kind of off-putting, mint, liquorice and botanical for me.  Palate is a little better, for a rye though it's kinda sweet...as much as I like mint and liquorice  though I don't want it in my whiskey.

There is a pleasant semi-sweet, cinnamon/honey flavor at first that was new and enjoyable. And then the aftertaste lingers on into the plain, familiar MGP Rye flavor notes. 
I didn't quite sense a blend of flavors... It's kind of like Diet Cola (not those modern zero sugar ones; the old Diet sodas) where it tastes like the original at first, but ends up with that bitter, synthetic flavor at the end. Just making an analogy; not saying MGP Rye is bitter, synthetic, or a bad thing (I do enjoy MGP rye whiskey a lot). I just think the MGP portion may be slightly overwhelming the overall scent and flavors of this whisky.
Very nice. Smooth and quite spicy. I really get a lot of mint or eucalyptus. Finishes with just a hint of caramel.
Good when first opened. Not as good a month later

Lemon/citrus, spicy tingle and some tannic astringency. Earthy hebacious flavor with intense rye spice, low ethanol presence.

Long warming dry finish

While I am not a big fan of gin, this rye has some spicy floral notes very similar to gin (even hints of juniper) - but I find it VERY enjoyable and well balanced in this High West bottle. A very smooth yet refreshingly different whiskey to have in the collection.

This is a lovely Rye whiskey insomuch as it delivers spice and floral notes in the same moment. It’s very complex with a slightly sweet base and the consistency of a delightful mouthful of spice clear through a nice long finish. I’m very impressed with the ever changing profile based on what I may have eaten before sipping. I’ve sipped it a number of times before writing this review, and as always, neat with a few drops of water.
Lighter flavors with subtle spice and heat. Nothing offensive here. Smooth. It was accidentally served to me on a large rock that melted quickly, so that may be part of the “lightness”.
very smooth and rich slight floral notes, incredible spice! I have never tasted a rye like this one of my new favorites. 92 proof too so there is a little  heat after you sip

This is one of my favorite ryes for use in an old-fashioned.  
Lots of tart fruit on the nose, cinnamon and cedar behind Granny Smith apples balanced by some vanilla
Soft palate with late warmth sweeter than I expected
The oak comes through later.
Barrel notes come through the finish. This is well balanced and delicious.

This noses with the anise and dill super heavy, which makes sense for an MGP profile. Appreciate the baking spice as well. Hits the palate a bit thin (smooth?) but with the rye spice up front with a black pepper and dill finish. Really tasty and a great offering from high west at the price point.
Leather and licorice nose. Tastes like toned-down, liquid, red hot candies. Long spicy finish. Really like it, but not as much as Jack Daniel’s Single Barrel Rye.
Perfect amount of spice with a slight tartness. Easy drink

All things including price considered, this is one of my absolute favorite rye whiskeys to date and a staple in my cabinet. This is my daily driver and I always have a bottle in my rotation. I typically enjoy it neat and at $35.00 a bottle it is one of the best at this price point. It has the sting and heat of young rye up front that I personally love but is balanced out quite nicely by the finish. Even with High West now using thier own young distillate this entry remains excellent.
N - honey, oak, mint
P - rye spice, vanilla, carmelized sugar 
F - long, hot, honey, tobacco

(Taken neat. Let sit for ~5 minutes.)

Nose: Caramel, minty, sweet;
Palate: Burnt caramel, butterscotch, rice Krispies; STRONG BITE
Finish: Lingering; Long

I like this 

Spicy - clooooves? You tell me 

This puppy burns with an aftershock on the tongue which is nice

Would drink again

So pleasant. Vanilla, spice, honey, mint and oak and a lovely oak finish...Beautiful chilled, but amazing in a proper Manhattan with Antica and Angostura or Orange Bitters (and a proper Maraschino). I’ve been a George Dickel/Woodford Rye fan but this is fantastic at the price point.

Nose: sweet..orange peel. Smallest hint of artificial banana that I don’t like. Otherwise a shallow nose. 
Palate: smooth, low in complexity low in spice, maybe fraction of tobacco but.. not bad but nothing jumps out. Maybe cherry, so fruit overwhelms any chance of others
A solid all around rye. Not too spicy and perfect in a Manhattan
Love it. Great cinnamon and spice on front of palate quickly leads into smooth sweet caramel
Pretty simple. Little bit of burn. Apple pie sweetness. Short finish
Great Value whiskey! Good spice flavors; star anise and cinnamon. Finishes with a little sweetness and oak
Much sweeter than expected, maybe the ice ball did that. Longer finish, good taste. Worth the buy, good in an old fashion
Pretty fly for a rye guy! Never been a huge rye fan but this one really changed my mind. Packed with flavor!
Smooth. Buttery, apple, cinnamon. A touch of spice.
One of my first ryes, very delicious flavor. Very drinkable and a little spicy.
I love this rye! Complex, sweet, spicy, subtle but flavorful.

Nose: lots of mint and herbal with a little smoke

Taste: flowery with a little bit of spice. Some mint and oak flavors
Spicy up front with a nice vanilla caramel finish

Licorice spice nose, spicy cinnamon peppermint sweetness taste with a spicy finish

Taken neat

Sweeter on the rocks
Really enjoy on the rocks, not my favorite Manhattan pour
The nose carries dill, fruits, and lots of spice. The spice continues into the taste. It’s sweet and has a nice texture at first. A little oily. Finishes with heat and lemon zest.

Nose - Candied vanilla, several herbal notes.
Taste - Oily, some oak, Christmas spice, brown sugar, gin/juniper.
Finish - Long, slight spice burn.

This is an extremely well-rounded rye whiskey that is not overpowered by rye spice. Every sip is a smorgasbord of different flavors that are hard to identify. This is a funky adventure that is a good sipper and would make an excellent cocktail.

Hmm definitely different. The nose reminded me of a herbal medicinal incense type thing going on.

The palate was as people have noted a clove, juniper spearmint type of combo. Not really what I'm after in a dram.

It's well balanced out, good oily backbone but all for naught if you aren't partial to the individual flavour components. Nice warming afterglow.
Sweet, oaky, nutty, leathery. All night rye. My favorite pick in the $30 price range.
Spicy with cinnamon on the front. Sweet caramel on the finish
This is definitely what rye tastes like with no frills. Solid pour, but nothing truly special.

Batch no. 20C12; An extremely interesting and enjoyable whisky. The gin jumps out at you in the nose and palate. However, if you look behind it you will get a toasted vanilla woodiness and traditional rye spice/sassafras flavor. The finish lingers, there is some oil here. It's the pine needles from the gin still, along with the sassafras or black licorice sweetness. I did find a tad of new leather every once in awhile as well. After a few minutes it all gets rounded up with the menthol I get from a Lagavulin. For the price this is an excellent whisky for enthusiastic drammers. I look forward to trying other High West bottlings!
Tart apple juice and baking spices with a bit of barrel char. Fairly long finish of licorice candy.

Such an amazing smell. So many flavors I couldn't pick out I actually had to "cheat" and look up some tasting notes on this one. I can get the pine, and anise. Good light rye notes during tasting. Think what you want of MGP, this is pretty delicious.
